makers.displaydate: 1938–2024; born San Francisco, CA; died Orient, NY; active New York, NY
makers.displaymaker: Richard Serra, 1938–2024; born San Francisco, CA; died Orient, NY; active New York, NY

texts.textentryhtml:
The title of this work alludes to Serra’s Weight and Measure, a sculpture temporarily installed at the Tate Modern, London, in 1992, in which two steel cubes were placed at opposite sides of an otherwise empty gallery. WM III is one of a series of etchings in which Serra varied the spatial relationships between the white paper and the black squares of ink that compose each print’s image. By shifting the position of the etching plates and the paper size from print to print, he created an effect through which the black etched squares—all printed using the same plate—seem to shift in size, weight, and even shape. For Serra, "Black is a property, not a quality. In terms of weight, black is heavier, creates a larger volume, holds itself in a more compressed field."

The Hedgehog and the Fox, located near Princeton Stadium, is an example of the monumental Cor-Ten steel sculpture for which Serra is renowned.

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 2000," Record of the Princeton University Art Museum 60 (2001): p. 66-93.
bibliography.citation: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 2000," Record of the Princeton University Art Museum 60 (2001): p. 66-93., p. 75
